_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

Seven things that lead to the decline of: Missing out on seeing the mendicants
Neglecting to listen to the true teaching
Not training in higher ethical conduct
Being suspicious about mendicants, whether senior, junior, or middle
Listening to the teaching with a hostile, fault-finding mind
Seeking outside of the Buddhist community for those worthy of religious donations and serving them first
These seven things lead to the decline of a lay follower
Seven things that don’t lead to the decl: Not missing out on seeing the mendicants
Not neglecting to listen to the true teaching
Being confident about mendicants, whether senior, junior, or middle
Not listening to the teaching with a hostile, fault-finding mind
Not seeking outside of the Buddhist community for those worthy of religious donations and serving them first
These seven things don’t lead to the decline of a lay follower
Seven principles leading to decline [an7: Missing out on seeing those who are evolved and listening to the teachings of the Noble One
Not training in higher ethical conduct
Wanting to listen to the true teaching with a fault-finding mind
Seeking outside the Buddhist community for someone else worthy of religious donations and serving them first
A lay follower who practices them falls away from the true teaching
These seven principles leading to decline have been well taught
Seven principles that prevent decline [a: Not missing out on seeing those who are evolved and listening to the teachings of the Noble One
Wanting to listen to the true teaching without a fault-finding mind
Not seeking outside the Buddhist community for someone else worthy of religious donations and serving the Buddhist community first
A lay follower who practices them doesn’t fall away from the true teaching
These seven principles that prevent decline have been well taught.
